security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown files with .NET/C# coding guidelines. No executable code, no network access, no external commands. Uses standard development tools (Read, Edit, Grep, Glob) appropriate for code review tasks.

content.value_statement: Manually reviewing .NET code for naming conventions and patterns is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill provides automated checks for PascalCase naming, modern C# patterns, async best practices, and common anti-patterns.
actual_capabilities: Check naming conventions (PascalCase, camelCase, underscore prefixes)
Identify outdated patterns (String vs string, List<T> vs new())
Flag async anti-patterns (async void, blocking calls)
Suggest modern C# features (records, file-scoped namespaces)
limitations: Does not execute or test code
Does not check for logic errors or bugs
Does not validate XML documentation comments
Does not analyze performance or security issues

prompt_templates.title: Quick Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this C# code for naming conventions and Microsoft patterns: [paste code]

prompt_templates.title: Refactor Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Refactor this code to use modern C# 10+ features: [paste code]

prompt_templates.title: Pattern Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Check this code for async/await anti-patterns: [paste code]

prompt_templates.title: Best Practices
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a CustomerService class following Microsoft conventions with ILogger and repository pattern

output_examples.input: Review this code: public class customerService { private String strName; public async void GetData() { var result = GetAsync().Result; } }
output: NAMING ISSUES: customerService should be CustomerService (PascalCase)
String should be string (use language keyword)
async void should be async Task (unless event handler)
.Result causes deadlock risk - use await instead

best_practices: Use language keywords (string, int, bool) instead of .NET types (String, Int32, Boolean)
Always suffix async methods with Async and accept CancellationToken parameter
Apply file-scoped namespaces and target-typed new (new()) for modern C# 10+
Use records (record) for immutable DTOs instead of classes with manual equality
anti_patterns: Using Hungarian notation (strName, iCount) or screaming caps (MAX_SIZE)
Catching base Exception without re-throwing or specific handling
Blocking on async code with .Result, .Wait(), or Task.WaitAll()
Missing using statements for IDisposable resources or async void methods

faq.question: Which .NET versions are supported?
faq.answer: Supports .NET 6+ and C# 10+ patterns including records, file-scoped namespaces, and primary constructors.

faq.question: Does this skill check EditorConfig rules?
faq.answer: The skill checks for EditorConfig files and defers to their rules when present for style preferences.

faq.question: Can this skill write code fixes?
faq.answer: Yes, use the Edit tool or ask for refactoring suggestions to apply naming and pattern improvements.

faq.question: Is my code data safe?
faq.answer: Yes, this is a prompt-based skill. Code is processed in context and never sent to external services.

faq.question: Why are my variable names flagged?
faq.answer: The skill follows Microsoft naming conventions: parameters/locals use camelCase, private fields use _camelCase, constants use PascalCase.

faq.question: How is this different from Roslyn analyzers?
faq.answer: This skill provides contextual guidance and explanations. Roslyn analyzers enforce rules at compile time automatically.
